summary: This document is a plea agreement and sentencing order for Jeffrey Epstein from the Circuit Court of Palm Beach County. It details his guilty plea to two felony counts, the resulting sentences (18 months total incarceration plus community control), and the legal requirements for his registration as a sexual offender under Florida law. This document is a section of Florida state law (likely from Chapter 943) detailing the registration requirements, lifetime obligations, and legal penalties for sexual offenders. It specifies conditions for removal from the registry, reporting schedules, and the legal framework for public safety. It does not mention any specific individuals related to the Epstein case.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The individual pleading guilty to two felony counts: solicitation of prostitution and procuring a person under 18 for prostitution. He is sentenced to incarceration and designated as a sexual offender.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleads guilty to two felony counts (solicitation of prostitution and procuring a person under 18 for prostitution) and is sentenced to 12 months and 6 months consecutive incarceration, followed by 12 months of community control with strict conditions.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to felony solicitation of prostitution (Case 06CF009454AMB) and felony procuring a person under 18 for prostitution (Case 08CF009381AMB).
He was sentenced to a total of 18 months in the Palm Beach County Detention Facility (12 months + 6 months consecutive), with credit for 1 day served, followed by 12 months of community control.
A special condition of his community control was to have no unsupervised contact with minors, with any supervising adult requiring approval from the Department of Corrections.
Epstein was formally designated as a Sexual Offender pursuant to Florida Statute 943.0435, triggering extensive registration and reporting requirements.
The document includes the full text of Florida Statute 943.0435, detailing the legal obligations and penalties for sexual offenders in the state.
The document is a Florida statute outlining sexual offender registration requirements, not a case-specific document about Jeffrey Epstein.
It establishes that sexual offenders must generally maintain registration for life unless specific legal conditions are met, such as a full pardon.
The statute references the federal Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 as a standard for removing registration requirements.
It criminalizes assisting a sexual offender in eluding law enforcement or failing to report noncompliance, classifying it as a third-degree felony.
The law mandates in-person re-registration at a sheriff's office at specified intervals, with more frequent reporting for offenders convicted of certain serious offenses against minors.
